unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: 2 Proportion z-Intervals: 2-sided Testing
question_text:
A two-sample $z$-test for proportions had the hypotheses:
$${ H }_{ 0 }:{ p }_{ 1 }-{ p }_{ 2 }=0$$ $${ H }_{ a }:{ p }_{ 1 }-{ p }_{ 2 }\neq 0$$
The test produces a $p$-value of $0.04$.
Which of the following must be TRUE?
I. A $90\%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions will contain the value $0$.
II. A $95\%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions will contain the value $0$.
III. A $99\%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions will contain the value $0$.
solution:
We want the interval to contain $0$, meaning that we fail to reject the null hypotheses. In order to solve for this, we need to figure out the significance level of each one of the intervals and see if the $p$-value falls above or below the significance level.

Statement I. For a $90\%$ confidence interval, the significance level is $10\%$. Since our $p$-value of $0.04 < 0.10$, we reject the null hypotheses. Therefore, Statement I is false.

Statement II. For a $95\%$ confidence interval, the significance level is $5\%$. Since our $p$-value of $0.04<0.05$, we reject the null hypotheses. Therefore, Statement II is false.

Statement III. For a $99\%$ confidence interval, the significance level is $1\%$. Since our $p$-value of $0.04>0.01$ we fail to reject the null hypotheses. Therefore, Statement III is true.
